greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows in which row n lists in nondecreasing order the smallest part of every partition of n that do not contain 1 as a part, with a(1) = 1.
comment: For n >= 2, row n lists the parts of the head of the last section of the set of partitions of n, except the emergent parts.
Also 1 together with the integers > 1 of A196931.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..33, flattened
example: Row n has length A002865(n), n >= 2. The sum of row n is A182708(n), n >= 2. The number of 2's in row n is A002865(n-2), n >= 4. Right border of triangle gives A000027.
maple: b:= proc(n, i) option remember; local g, j, r;
if n=0 then [1] elif i<2 then [0]
for j to n/i do g:= b(n-i*j, i-1);
T:= proc(n) local l; l:= b(n$2);
mathematica: p[f_, g_] := Plus @@ PadRight[{f, g}]; b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = Module[{ g, j, r}, Which[n == 0, {1}, i<2, {0}, True, r = b[n, i-1]; For[j = 1, j <= n/i, j++, g = b[n-i*j, i-1]; r = p[p[r, Append[Array[0&, i], g // First]], ReplacePart[g, 1 -> 0]]]; r]]; T[n_] := Module[{l}, l = b[n, n]; If[n == 1, {1}, Table[Array[i&, l[[i+1]]], {i, 2, Length[l]-1}] // Flatten]]; Table[T[n], {n, 1, 16}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 30 2014, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Oct 21 2011
